articles.headline: Microsoft and Google Grapple for Supremacy
articles.snippet: The Microsoft-Google rivalry is shaping up as a titanic corporate clash for the ages.
articles.abstract: The Microsoft-Google rivalry is shaping up as a titanic corporate clash for the ages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Microsoft-Google rivalry is shaping up as a titanic corporate clash for the ages.

articles.headline: Northrop Makes Pitch for Storm Aid
articles.snippet: Northrop Grumman Corporation is lobbying Congress for $200 million to cover losses caused by Hurricane Katrina.
articles.abstract: Northrop Grumman Corporation is lobbying Congress for $200 million to cover losses caused by Hurricane Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 9 — The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the largest builder of warships in the world, was on a charm offensive here Tuesday. Armed with slides and charts, Philip A. Teel, who runs Northrop's shipyards, led a phalanx of executives who laid out their case for another $200 million from Congress to cover losses from Hurricane Katrina.

articles.headline: Iranian Letter: Using Religion to Lecture Bush
articles.snippet: Iran's president wrote to President Bush that the invasion of Iraq could not be reconciled with Christian values.
articles.abstract: Iran's president wrote to President Bush that the invasion of Iraq could not be reconciled with Christian values.

articles.headline: Alarmed by Raids, Neighbors Stand Guard in Iraq
articles.snippet: Sunni Arab neighborhoods in Baghdad have begun forming citizen groups to keep Shiite police forces out of their areas.
articles.abstract: Sunni Arab neighborhoods in Baghdad have begun forming citizen groups to keep Shiite police forces out of their areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 9 — It was almost 3 a.m. in Zubaida Square in central Baghdad last week when headlights signaled one flash, then two, then one again.

articles.headline: Executives Take Company Planes as if Their Own
articles.snippet: On top of sharply rising executive salaries, shareholders are paying more for executives' personal travel on jets.
articles.abstract: On top of sharply rising executive salaries, shareholders are paying more for executives' personal travel on jets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard D. Parsons, chairman and chief executive of Time Warner, owns a small vineyard in Tuscany that produces a Brunello di Montalcino selling for $80 a bottle, adorned with a crest of the Parsons family.

articles.headline: Northrop Makes Pitch for Storm Aid
articles.snippet: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the largest builder of warships in the world, was on a charm offensive here Tuesday. Armed with slides and charts, Philip A. Teel, who runs Northrop's shipyards, led a phalanx of executives who laid out their case...
articles.abstract: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the largest builder of warships in the world, was on a charm offensive here Tuesday. Armed with slides and charts, Philip A. Teel, who runs Northrop's shipyards, led a phalanx of executives who laid out their case for another $200 million from Congress to cover losses from Hurricane Katrina.     By Pentagon standards, a request measured in millions of dollars, rather than billions, may seem like small change. But Northrop's effort is emerging as a test case of whether such a large company should receive extra help from taxpayers or bear its financial difficulties on its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 9 - The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the largest builder of warships in the world, was on a charm offensive here Tuesday. Armed with slides and charts, Philip A. Teel, who runs Northrop's shipyards, led a phalanx of executives who laid out their case for another $200 million from Congress to cover losses from Hurricane Katrina.

articles.headline: Microsoft and Google Grapple for Supremacy
articles.snippet: The Microsoft-Google rivalry is shaping up as a titanic corporate clash for the ages.     It may not turn out that way. Markets and corporate fortunes routinely defy prediction. But it sure looks as if the two companies are on a collision course, ...
articles.abstract: The Microsoft-Google rivalry is shaping up as a titanic corporate clash for the ages.     It may not turn out that way. Markets and corporate fortunes routinely defy prediction. But it sure looks as if the two companies are on a collision course, as the realms of desktop computing and Internet services and software overlap more and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Microsoft-Google rivalry is shaping up as a titanic corporate clash for the ages.

articles.headline: Executives Take Company Planes as if Their Own
articles.snippet: Richard D. Parsons, chairman and chief executive of Time Warner, owns a small vineyard in Tuscany that produces a Brunello di Montalcino selling for $80 a bottle, adorned with a crest of the Parsons family.     Twice a year, he boards one of his c...
articles.abstract: Richard D. Parsons, chairman and chief executive of Time Warner, owns a small vineyard in Tuscany that produces a Brunello di Montalcino selling for $80 a bottle, adorned with a crest of the Parsons family.     Twice a year, he boards one of his company's four jets to visit his 20 acres in Italy. When he does, Time Warner shareholders pick up the bill.

articles.headline: Whole Foods Talks Dollars and Cents
articles.snippet: With its white-apron-clad chefs, who whip up almond crusted flounder for $14.99 a pound, and its rows of hard to pronounce cheeses (consider bleu D'Auvergne, best paired with a Rhône red wine), Whole Foods Market has always felt like the Saks Fift...
articles.abstract: With its white-apron-clad chefs, who whip up almond crusted flounder for $14.99 a pound, and its rows of hard to pronounce cheeses (consider bleu D'Auvergne, best paired with a Rhône red wine), Whole Foods Market has always felt like the Saks Fifth Avenue of supermarkets.     But the organic food emporium, all but synonymous with gastronomic indulgence, now wants to be known for something else: low prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: With its white-apron-clad chefs, who whip up almond crusted flounder for $14.99 a pound, and its rows of hard to pronounce cheeses (consider bleu D'Auvergne, best paired with a Rhône red wine), Whole Foods Market has always felt like the Saks Fifth Avenue of supermarkets.

articles.headline: The High Costs of Cheap Gas and Vice Versa
articles.snippet: BEFORE we were old enough to have jobs, my college roommate and I set out to take a vacation that would cost as little as possible. Our transportation was a borrowed Volkswagen, and friends scattered around the country put us up on spare beds or s...
articles.abstract: BEFORE we were old enough to have jobs, my college roommate and I set out to take a vacation that would cost as little as possible. Our transportation was a borrowed Volkswagen, and friends scattered around the country put us up on spare beds or sofas. Entertainment came from a carefully planned schedule of minor league baseball games and from whatever else caught our eye along the way.     The first trip, in 1992, went so well that it became a near-annual tradition. By the time we stopped it eight years later, we had been to both coasts, the Smoky Mountains, the Great Plains, the Herbert Hoover museum and perhaps the nation's finest ballpark food stand, a barbecue pit in Stockton, Calif. On a good day, we spent $50 between us.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEFORE we were old enough to have jobs, my college roommate and I set out to take a vacation that would cost as little as possible. Our transportation was a borrowed Volkswagen, and friends scattered around the country put us up on spare beds or sofas. Entertainment came from a carefully planned schedule of minor league baseball games and from whatever else caught our eye along the way.

articles.headline: POLL GIVES BUSH WORST MARKS YET ON MAJOR ISSUES
articles.snippet: Americans have a bleaker view of the country's direction than at any time in more than two decades, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Sharp disapproval of President Bush's handling of gasoline prices has combined with intensifi...
articles.abstract: Americans have a bleaker view of the country's direction than at any time in more than two decades, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Sharp disapproval of President Bush's handling of gasoline prices has combined with intensified unhappiness about Iraq to create a grim political environment for the White House and Congressional Republicans.     Mr. Bush's approval ratings for his management of foreign policy, Iraq and the economy have fallen to the lowest levels of his presidency. He drew poor marks on the issues that have been at the top of the national agenda in recent months, in particular immigration and gasoline prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans have a bleaker view of the country's direction than at any time in more than two decades, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Sharp disapproval of President Bush's handling of gasoline prices has combined with intensified unhappiness about Iraq to create a grim political environment for the White House and Congressional Republicans.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Megan Thee

articles.headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Agree to Extend Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: House and Senate Republicans reached agreement Tuesday on a $69 billion bill that would extend President Bush's tax cuts for investors for two more years and temporarily block a big jump in the alternative minimum tax.     The agreement, which has...
articles.abstract: House and Senate Republicans reached agreement Tuesday on a $69 billion bill that would extend President Bush's tax cuts for investors for two more years and temporarily block a big jump in the alternative minimum tax.     The agreement, which has a good chance of passing both chambers later this week, would lock in one of Mr. Bush's signature tax cuts through 2010 and give Republicans a victory at a time when most of their other efforts have stalled.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 9 - House and Senate Republicans reached agreement Tuesday on a $69 billion bill that would extend President Bush's tax cuts for investors for two more years and temporarily block a big jump in the alternative minimum tax.

articles.headline: Bush Aides Struggling With Yuan
articles.snippet: After nearly three years of pushing China to let its currency float more freely, with only modest results, the Bush administration still appears reluctant to accuse China of manipulating its exchange rate.     On Wednesday, the Treasury Department...
articles.abstract: After nearly three years of pushing China to let its currency float more freely, with only modest results, the Bush administration still appears reluctant to accuse China of manipulating its exchange rate.     On Wednesday, the Treasury Department plans to release its latest assessment of Chinese foreign exchange practices and declare whether or not they represent a form of manipulation aimed at artificially increasing Chinese exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 8 - After nearly three years of pushing China to let its currency float more freely, with only modest results, the Bush administration still appears reluctant to accuse China of manipulating its exchange rate.

articles.headline: Clash Foreseen Between C.I.A. and Pentagon
articles.snippet: President Bush's selection of Gen. Michael V. Hayden to be the next director of the Central Intelligence Agency sets the stage for new wrangling with the Pentagon, which is rapidly expanding its own global spying and terrorist-tracking operations,...
articles.abstract: President Bush's selection of Gen. Michael V. Hayden to be the next director of the Central Intelligence Agency sets the stage for new wrangling with the Pentagon, which is rapidly expanding its own global spying and terrorist-tracking operations, both long considered C.I.A. roles.      Overseeing Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's drive to broaden the military's clandestine reconnaissance and man-hunting missions is Stephen A. Cambone, the Pentagon's intelligence czar and one of Mr. Rumsfeld's most trusted aides, whose low public profile masks his influence as one of the nation's most powerful intelligence officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 9 - President Bush's selection of Gen. Michael V. Hayden to be the next director of the Central Intelligence Agency sets the stage for new wrangling with the Pentagon, which is rapidly expanding its own global spying and terrorist-tracking operations, both long considered C.I.A. roles.

articles.headline: Iranian Letter: Using Religion to Lecture Bush
articles.snippet: With the tone of a teacher and the certainty of a believer, the president of Iran wrote to President Bush that Western democracy had failed and that the invasion of Iraq, American treatment of prisoners and support for Israel could not be reconcil...
articles.abstract: With the tone of a teacher and the certainty of a believer, the president of Iran wrote to President Bush that Western democracy had failed and that the invasion of Iraq, American treatment of prisoners and support for Israel could not be reconciled with Christian values.      Locked in a conflict with the West over its nuclear program, the Iranian, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, made the observations in a letter on Monday that the Iranian government said ''raised new ways of solving problems.''

articles.headline: Alarmed by Raids, Neighbors Stand Guard in Iraq
articles.snippet: It was almost 3 a.m. in Zubaida Square in central Baghdad last week when headlights signaled one flash, then two, then one again.      From the darkness, someone signaled back. The watchers were there.
articles.abstract: It was almost 3 a.m. in Zubaida Square in central Baghdad last week when headlights signaled one flash, then two, then one again.      From the darkness, someone signaled back. The watchers were there.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 9 - It was almost 3 a.m. in Zubaida Square in central Baghdad last week when headlights signaled one flash, then two, then one again.
